message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms of hypothyroidism, including fatigue, weight gain, constipation, myalgias, cold intolerance, and delayed deep tendon reflex relaxation. The best initial screening test for hypothyroidism is serum TSH. Levels of anti-thyroid peroxidase (TPO) antibodies would be helpful in diagnosing autoimmune thyroiditis, but not as the initial screening test. Morning cortisol and plasma ACTH would be helpful in evaluating adrenal insufficiency, but not as the initial screening test. Hemoglobin and hematocrit would be helpful in evaluating anemia, but not as the initial screening test.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest hypothyroidism. The best initial screening test is Serum TSH, as it is the most sensitive test for hypothyroidism. Cortisol and ACTH levels are useful for assessing adrenal function, and TPO antibodies can aid in the diagnosis of autoimmune thyroid disease, but neither is the best initial screening test in this case. Hemoglobin and hematocrit may be useful in assessing for anemia, which can cause fatigue, but they are not the best initial screening test for hypothyroidism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially cold intolerance and constipation, suggest hypothyroidism. Delayed deep tendon reflex relaxation is also a symptom. The best initial screening test for hypothyroidism is serum TSH. Therefore, option (C) is correct. Hemoglobin and hematocrit are not specific for hypothyroidism. Anti-TPO antibodies and morning cortisol and plasma ACTH can be used to confirm diagnosis but are not the first screening tests.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest hypothyroidism, and the best initial screening test is serum TSH. Options A and B are not related to thyroid function, and option D will be useful in evaluating for anemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest hypothyroidism, and the best initial screening test for hypothyroidism is serum TSH. The delay in deep tendon reflex relaxation also supports this diagnosis. The other options may be done to further evaluate the cause of the hypothyroidism but are not the best initial screening test.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with hypothyroidism, and the best initial screening test for this condition is serum TSH. All other options are not as specific for hypothyroidism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient shows signs of hypothyroidism, which can cause fatigue, weight gain, constipation, myalgias, and cold intolerance. A delayed deep tendon reflex relaxation is also a sign of hypothyroidism. The best initial screening test for this patient is serum TSH to check for thyroid dysfunction. Option A, level of anti-TPO antibodies, is a diagnostic test for autoimmune thyroiditis. Option B, morning cortisol and plasma ACTH, is a diagnostic test for adrenal insufficiency. Option D, hemoglobin and hematocrit, is a test for anemia, which does not seem to be the likely cause of the patient's symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is likely presenting with hypothyroidism, as the symptoms and physical exam findings are consistent with this diagnosis. The best initial screening test in this case is serum TSH, which is highly sensitive and specific for detecting hypothyroidism. Anti-TPO antibodies would be useful in confirming an autoimmune cause of hypothyroidism. Morning cortisol and plasma ACTH would be useful in evaluating for adrenal insufficiency. Hemoglobin and hematocrit would not be the most helpful screening test in this situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient complains of fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, and constipation, which are all symptoms of hypothyroidism. Delayed deep tendon reflex relaxation also suggests hypothyroidism. The best initial screening test for hypothyroidism is serum TSH. Levels of anti-thyroid peroxidase (TPO) antibodies may indicate autoimmune thyroiditis, but TSH is still a better initial screening test. Morning cortisol and plasma ACTH are used to evaluate for adrenal insufficiency, which is not likely in this case. Hemoglobin and hematocrit are not specific for hypothyroidism.

Level of anti-thyroid peroxidase antibodies is used for evaluating autoimmune thyroid disease. Morning cortisol and plasma ACTH are used for evaluating adrenal insufficiency.
